perturbation.explanation: By removing the indemnification obligation for losses arising from 'Licensee’s Commercialization of the Licensed Products in the Field in the Territory,' the contract attempts to circumvent potential liability for harm caused to consumers due to the commercialization of the drug. This omission contradicts consumer protection laws and regulations in the United States that hold companies responsible for ensuring that their products are safe and properly marketed. Removing this clause puts consumers at risk, especially since it involves pharmaceuticals, where safety and proper usage are paramount.
perturbation.contradicted_law: U.S. consumer protection laws and regulations (e.g., FDA regulations, state product liability laws)

13.3
Indemnification Procedure. With respect to any indemnification obligations of either Party under this
Agreement, the following conditions must be met for such indemnification obligations to become applicable:
(a)
The Party requesting the indemnification (Indemnified Party) shall notify the other Party
(Indemnifying Party) promptly in writing of any claim which may give rise to an obligation on the part of Indemnifying Party
hereunder;
(b)
The Indemnified Party shall use commercially reasonable efforts to avoid or mitigate any Losses which
the Indemnified Party may suffer as a result of the Indemnifying Party’s breach or wrongdoing; and
(c)
To the extent Losses are the result of a Third Party claim, suit, action or proceeding (Third Party
Claim), (i) the Indemnified Party shall not without the prior consent in writing of the Indemnifying Party make any admission or
otherwise do anything, which may prejudice the defense against such a Third Party Claim; (ii) Indemnifying Party shall be allowed to
timely undertake the sole control of the defense of any such Third Party Claim, including all negotiations for the settlement, or
compromise of such claim or action at its sole expense; and (iii) the Indemnified Party shall at its expense render reasonable
assistance, information, co-operation and authority to permit Indemnifying Party to defend such Third Party Claim.

perturbation.explanation: The omission of clause (b), which requires the Indemnified Party to 'use commercially reasonable efforts to avoid or mitigate any Losses,' removes a key obligation for loss mitigation. This creates a loophole where the indemnified party may not take appropriate steps to minimize damages, potentially increasing the financial burden on the indemnifying party and, by extension, impacting consumers if the losses are passed on through higher prices or reduced services. This is against the general principles of U.S. contract law and the duty to mitigate damages, which aims to prevent unnecessary losses.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of U.S. contract law; Duty to mitigate damages

perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase 'except to the extent that such limitation of liability is contrary to the Applicable Law or any such special, non-compensatory, consequential, indirect, incidental, statutory or punitive damages have been awarded to a Third Party under a Third Party Claim,' the contract attempts to create an absolute limitation of liability, regardless of whether such a limitation is permissible under U.S. law. This is a contradiction of the legal principle that limitations of liability cannot shield a party from liability to the extent prohibited by applicable laws, especially in cases of gross negligence, intentional misconduct, or violations of consumer protection statutes. This would be especially risky for pharmaceuticals, as consumers harmed by unsafe or improperly marketed drugs may have limited recourse due to the blanket liability waiver.
perturbation.contradicted_law: U.S. contract law regarding limitations of liability; Consumer protection laws; Product liability laws
